The two vessels were the FATEH REHMAN of about 45 tons of Koweit, and the BOOM SAMHAN oi 49 tons of Khatar. Both these places are ports on the Eastern coast of Arabia about 250 miles apart. Koweit being near Basrah. Both dhows made Panjim for water on April 1st, 1942, and left on April 3rd, 1942. As winds were not favourable they sailed due west for 204 miles. On Ai-ril 9th at sunrise they sighted a large submarine about 600 yards away due North and heading towards them. Hie submarine loot no time in firing a few shells without any warning. Some fell short but one caught the FATEH REHMAN almost amidships and' she sank immediately. The submarine next tui’ned her attention to the BOOM SAMHAN and a couple of shells made her heel over and sent her crew scrambling into the water. Y/hile the BOOM SAMHAN was still lying on her side with the crew in the water, the submarine passed between both the struggling crews. The vessels at the tine they were fired on were about 150 yards apart. The Master of Hie BOOM SAMHAN who was still clinging to the side of his vessel, called out to the 3 or 4 men on the conning tower to save the crews. No notice was however taken and the submarine proceeded in a southerly direction. The Master of the BOOM SAMHAN is definite that the men on the tower of the submarine were not Japs but either Germans or Italians. The hull of the submarine was painted with bands of black, blue and black, one below the other. The jolly boat of the FATEH REHMAN sank with the vessel, as it also received a shell. The jolly boat of the BOOM SAMHAN being behind the overturned vessel was evidently not visible to the submarine, who probably expected both the vessels to be sunk without trace. As soon as the submarine fired, the crew waved their national flags, but again this was ignored. When the submarine left, the crews of both dhows got into the jolly boat of the BOOM SAMHAN and, after salving as much as they could from the heavily listing . vessel, they set sail for the coast; i.e. due East at 2 p.m. During the encounter with the submarine no other vessels of any sort were visible, in fact they did not encounter any vessels till the 12th the day they landed at Malvan. physicalDescription.extent: The file’s contents are arranged in approximate chronological order, from the earliest item at the front to the latest at the end. The file notes at the end of the file (f 8) mirror the chronological arrangement.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 9; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-8; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file comprises copies of correspondence and reports relating to the sinking by an enemy (presumed Japanese) submarine of two dhows, belonging to Kuwait and Qatar, in the Indian Ocean, including: a copy of a letter from the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf (Lieutenant-Colonel William Rupert Hay) to the Secretary of State for India, dated 16 May 1942, concerning compensation for loss by enemy action, and reporting of the two lost dhows (ff 2-3); a copy of a report, dated 16 April 1942, sent by the Assistant Collector of Salt Revenues at Camp Malvan to the Staff Officer (Intelligence) at Bombay, reporting that thirty-five crewmen had arrived from one of the sunk vessels at Malvan, and enclosing a testimony of the attack and sinking by one of the crewmen (f 6).
